ygData.subject: SharpNEAT - initial success
ygData.msgSnippet: As some of you will be aware I have been working on a C# implementation of NEAT (which I have deciced to name SharpNEAT). The final pieces of the core code

Subject: SharpNEAT - initial success
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=127853030
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod

As some of you will be aware I have been working on a C# implementation 
of NEAT (which I have deciced to name SharpNEAT). The final pieces of 
the core code were put in place today and although I really should unit 
test some of the latest code I couldn't resist the temptation to fire it 
up using a prey capture domain I had coded for a previous EANN project.

Results?  so far so good - the prey capture domain is based on the one 
described in the 1996 paper "Incremental Evolution of Complex General 
Behavior" (Faustino Gomez, Risto Miikkulainen). Basically the task 
difficulty can be increased by giving the prey a varying number of head 
starts (0 to 4) and then gradually increasing it's speed from 0.0 to 1.0 
moves per domain time-slice.

The goal task is to solve 4, 1.0   (4 initial moves and a speed of 1.0). 
Previously the most difficult task I was able to solve was 4, 0.3.  
Things kind of ground to a halt after that. Using the new NEAT 
implementation is so far giving better results - so far it has 'solved' 
4, 0.8.  The best network currently passes 75/100 tests on 4, 1.0.  Not 
a bad start.

I've just added in code to amalgamate matching innovations per 
generation (as Ken mentions in the competitive coevolution paper). Ken, 
I wonder - do you amalgamate matching structures in your initial 
populations too? it would make sense to, currently I don't.

One remaining significant thing I'm not doing is elitist selection - my 
evolution algorithm is currently a pure roulette wheel selection. So 
this will likely improve things when I change it.

So there you go. I will spend some time unit testing / tweaking and 
hopefully I will have the 4, 1.0 test solved this week and I can move 
onto some visualisation and/or XML stuff maybe.

Colin.
